conversation.content: [exhausted] God, I've been staring at these cases for, what, nine hours now? [pause] Wait, wait wait wait. [very quickly] This is—oh my god, this actually matches perfectly. [gasp softly] The mother with disabilities, the wrongful eviction, the—[excited] holy shit, this is it! [laugh] I mean, the judge literally ruled that, um... that the landlord's failure to accommodate constitutes discrimination under both state AND federal law. [extremely happy] This is exactly what we needed! [pause] Oh wow, I just—[sniffle] Sorry, it's just, you know, the Johnsons have been through so much. [empathetically] Three kids, and they were gonna be on the street next week. [passionate] But this precedent, it's not just similar, it's basically identical to their situation. [relieved] The timeline, the documentation issues, even the, uh... even the specific medical conditions align. [crying while speaking] I can't believe we actually found it. [laugh hard] All those nights going through dusty law journals, and it was sitting in a, hmm, in a 2019 appellate decision from two counties over. [warm] They're going to keep their home. [very sincerely] After everything they've been through, they're actually going to win this. [chuckle]

subject: Your paralegal research finding the precedent that won an impossible case for a deserving family
